transcription.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
So I'm Stefan.
And today I want to talk about some of the design work
we did for our stable coin that's called Gyroscope.
And this is joint work with my co-founder Ariak Lagus
Mont.
So you imagine you want to build a stable coin?
So you have a crypto currency and you want to keep it stable.
And in some senses, it's always going to look like this.
You have some kind of reserve of assets.
And then people can mint and redeem coins against that assets.
And that's going to stabilize the price.
If the price is too high, they can mint new coins.
If the price is too low, they can redeem coins.
It's going to stabilize the market price.
And we call the primary market mechanism--
excuse me--
the primary market mechanism.
The thing that grants access to these assets
and that intermediates between mint and redeemers, which
are basically up-chosuers and the asset reserve.
Now, what are these assets?
Well, that depends on your design.
It could be many different things in a sandwich share design.
It could be-- it's basically an equity share, in a sense.
For something like a basis design,
it's something like a bond.
And in a reserve-backed design,
it's some portfolio of other assets.
And by the way, this is a design we are using for gyroscope.
It's reserve-backed.
Now, there are different situations we need to look at.
The kind of boring case is when the system is fully
collateralized and all the assets are perfectly liquid.
Because then this is just basically a pricing problem,
price the reserve assets.
And the somewhat more tricky case
is the system might be 100% collateralized.
But not all of these assets might be liquid.
So you cannot necessarily pay them out when people redeem.
And then there's the crisis situation
where the system actually becomes under collateralized.
And then you need to decide what to do.
And my talk is going to be about the design of this component
that basically designs what to do in such a situation.
What we are implementing for gyroscope
is a reserve of only liquid assets.
So we are not really considering this case,
but it would be maybe straightforward extension
of what we're doing.
So let's look at some examples of this.
If you look at die, you have the PSM, or a PXability Mechanism.
And it basically looks like this that your reserve almost
only consists of USDC.
And this is what people sometimes say
that die has become-- or is going in the direction of wrapped USDC.
The numbers are like 60% or like the PSM, USDC.
Then you have another 20% of LP shares against USDC.
And of course, in that situation, something you need to ask
is are there many risks associated with that?
So for USDC, for example, there could
be some regulatory risk, which may amount
to counterparty risk, censorship risk, and so on.
Kind of the goal of gyroscope was to build something like a PSM 2.0.
So how might you improve on this design?
And I think there are like two ways.
The first thing is you may want to diversify your reserves.
You may not want to hold only USDC.
And the second thing is to implement something
like a programmatic risk control that reacts autonomously
to market conditions.
So that kind of can be seen in two parts.
The first one is if you have indyed
that different PSM vaults are independent,
but you probably want to coordinate them somehow
to react in the same way to market strategies.
And the other one is to price the stable coin,
depending on market conditions, especially
when the system should the system become under reserved.
And this is kind of where we're going.
So kind of to build such a system,
there are like many different challenges.
And I just want to give you like the super quick overview.
Basically, we want to make sure, right?
So we have a reserve that consists of different asset
classes that are probably structured in some way.
And then you need to answer several questions,
like which assets should that the--
which risks are these exposed to how
to structure the whole thing so that the risks are somehow
contained?
How do you generate details on the whole structure?
You probably want to price these things with Oracle,
and so on.
These are all things I'm not going to talk about,
but questions we still had to answer for gyroscope.
And today, I want to answer this mechanism.
Basically, the question is, someone comes to your system.
The system may be under reserved or illiquid to some degree.
They want to redeem a stable coin.
What is the amount of assets you offer them?
And to do that, we introduce a more general tool, which
is what we call the redemption curve.
And this is a general tool to analyze any stable coin design,
basically.
So the redemption curve is the following curve.
You have two axes.
On one axis, you have the redemption level,
which is basically the amount of stable coins
that are getting redeemed.
And on the other axis, you have the redemption price
that the mechanism offers to the redeemer.
And now we assume-- now we look at what
happens when people redeem more and more.
And market conditions don't change for the beginning.
So nothing happens.
No prices change.
But people just redeem more and more.
And ideally, of course, what you want is this curve.
You can always redeem at a dollar,
because then you always stabilize your peg at exactly a dollar.
And the higher your curvature here
is the less you support the peg as more and more people redeem.
Kind of the default that is also
happening for peg fiat currency is
that you try to support the peg as long as possible
until your reserve is empty and then you don't support it
anymore.
And kind of my argument will be that maybe this redemption
curve is not ideal and many other redemption curves
aren't ideal either.
So we can see this type of curve or that type of behavior
in the real world or in the fiat world.
For example, the attack on the British pound in the '90s
was basically a continuous outflow
from the British pound, basically a continuous redemption
of pounds against other assets until the central bank was no
longer willing to support the peg.
And then you see this kind of drop
where some people made a lot of money.
I think the recent crash of the pound
is probably not like that.
I can't say anything about that.
If we look at stable coins, we've seen similar behaviors.
The strata started a little bit outdated,
but there was this period in 2021 where
many creative stable coin designs were created
and many of them crashed in a somewhat similar way
very abruptly.
I want to look at one design case study, which would be FAY,
the original design of FAY, which was also not
very successful in its original form.
And so FAY had these direct incentives, which basically
means the more of peg, the whole system
is, the worse the price you're getting.
And that, if you look at it, it leads to a redemption curve
that is very steep and that looks about like this, which
means that your peg is not going to be stabilized very long.
Then they remove the direct incentives,
and then their redemption curve looked much less steep.
And we can see the effect of these steep redemption curve.
Here, I hope this is visible, this price of FAY after launch.
And it had a huge price drop with a lot of volatility.
I should probably talk about the elephant in the room
or maybe not elephant anymore.
Sanirad shares.
And the way I think about Sanirad shares is essentially
that you redeem at $1, but your backing is an endogenous asset
that's basically very, very tied into your project itself.
And this can lead to some negative feedback spirals.
So essentially, it's the same story as from the fiat world
before.
You provide redemption at $1 until the willingness
of the market to buy your Sanirad shares is exhausted.
And then you basically crash very rapidly.
And I should probably show this.
There's supply.

Or the amount of dollars people want

I should point out one thing about this particular talk.

This was not without precedent.
We had a very similar system called iron.

So here you have the stable coin that crashed
and at the same time, the endogenous collateral crashed

So that's not good.
And that's why we made gyroscope reserve backed.
And the basic idea of what I want to talk about today

as a design problem.
And maybe we should choose a redemption curve

And then we go and implement that in our primary market maker.
So the basic design is going to look like this, right?
You remember this picture.

What do we really want?

Because as you remember, the redemption curve

And of course, that doesn't happen in reality.
So the step from picking a curve and then implementing

And this is going to lead to this type of dynamic bonding
curve, if you want to think about it like that.
Great.
Let's first think about what we would ideally

First thing I want to note is that probably your collateralization
should stay above some lower bound.
Your redemption curve should not exhaust your reserve.
If that's at all possible.
And the reason for that is to enable the system to recover
later.
If you exhaust your reserve, you're basically
destroying your system.
And that's bad.
And then you probably also want the redemption price
to stay above a lower bound.
If that's possible to support the pack, at least to some degree.
Of course, this trivial-- we usually
want our stable count to be stable at $1.
You probably want some continuity of that curve.
You probably don't want these abrupt crashes.
And I would say the main reason for that

And that could also lead to all kinds of marketer people.
And then this is a little bit of a bonus.
But you want your redemption curve to be easy to use.
So probably what you want is you want the execution,

Our stable counts are going to be called drybells.
I'll call it for that.
You probably want that to be easy.
And especially you don't want there

and to be somehow clever about the way how people redeem.
We have a few bonus visitorata that

You probably want the reserve exhaustion to take a long time,
unless of course you reserve just there's crashes.
So the system should also kind of think

You should be able to regain your peg.
And of course you need to implement the whole thing on chain.
Yes, the first math equation.

Up until a certain amount of redemption.

And then we are going to drop the redemption price

ratio.
And this is a sustainable way of doing it.
So for example, if your system's 80% collateralized,

Nothing changes in the market.
